content: Aviation war risk insurance is essential for airlines, covering acts of violence like terrorism, hijackings, and sabotage. Airlines need this insurance for loan agreements, lease agreements, and to comply with foreign countries' requirements. After 9/11, the cost of war risk insurance increased, leading the U.S. government to expand the federal Aviation War Risk Insurance Program to ensure coverage for U.S. air carriers. The U.S. government expanded the federal Aviation War Risk Insurance Program to provide insurance coverage for U.S. air carriers when the commercial market was unable to do so. Private insurers now offer coverage for loss or damage to passengers and aircraft hulls in the event of a terrorist attack, but coverage for third-party damage caused by war or terrorism is limited. The private market for aviation risk insurance is deemed adequate, but could be impacted by a major terrorist incident. Commercial insurers provide war risk coverage for most airlines, including U.S. carriers. The aviation insurance market has been soft in recent years, with ample availability and lower prices. A well-constructed loss-sharing arrangement benefits both insurers. The federal government provides insurance programs for aviation war risk and terrorism risk. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Program, created by the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002, was established in response to the 9/11 attacks. It provided federal coverage for losses from terrorist attacks when the private sector was unable to offer affordable coverage. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Program, established in response to the 9/11 attacks, provides federal coverage for losses from terrorist attacks when the private sector is unable to offer affordable coverage. The program has been reauthorized multiple times due to the insurance industry's unwillingness to cover terrorism risk. The current version of the program does not directly provide coverage to businesses at risk of terrorism losses but offers government reinsurance for private insurers. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Program (TRIA) provides government reinsurance for private insurers offering specific commercial property/casualty coverage for terrorism losses. Private insurers are required to offer terrorism coverage and would cover any losses, with TRIA reimbursing them for some of their losses. There are no upfront premiums for government coverage, and any losses covered under TRIA would be paid from the government's general fund. Post-event recoupment fees on commercial insurance policies may be applied to recover the government's costs. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Program (TRIA) provides government reinsurance for private insurers offering commercial insurance coverage for terrorism losses. TRIA coverage is limited and operates through private insurers, with limits and deductibles from private insurance policies also applying. A minimum of $100 million in insured losses from a terrorist act is required for federal funds to flow under TRIA. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Program (TRIA) does not have federal limits on the cost of terrorism coverage. Private insurers must offer coverage under the same terms as insurance against other causes, but can charge a separate premium for terrorism coverage. State laws may limit terrorism premiums.
